name: Starving for a Solution Hunger as a Health Issue
Title: Starving for a Solution: Hunger as a Health Issue
Description:
Starving for a Solution: Hunger as a Health Issue

Starving for a Solution: Hunger as a Health Issue

By Randy Oostra, DM, FACHE

President and CEO, ProMedica

In countless kitchens, pantries and dining rooms across the country, one of America’s most dire public health crises is being served up. Every day, more than 41 million Americans, or 1 in 8 citizens, lack the essential nutrition they need to build and sustain good health.

Hunger is a health issue with far-reaching impact and detriment to both the personal vitality of scores of babies, youngsters, middle-aged people, and the elderly, as well as our collective well-being as a nation.

The health consequences of hunger can be seen every day in America’s emergency rooms, healthcare clinics, physician offices, and hospitals of every size and in every community – urban, suburban and rural.

People who are food insecure generally have irregular eating patterns and consume food with fewer nutrients, most often because they lack access to healthy, affordable foods. The absence of a consistent, healthy diet is linked to higher rates of obesity and the development of costly, acquired chronic diseases such as hypertension and type II diabetes – many of which are preventable or mitigated with proper nutrition and exercise.

Children experiencing food insecurity are also at a higher risk for developing chronic health conditions, including anemia and asthma. Sadly, they are also at greater risk for behavioral health issues such as anxiety and depression. Additionally, the social and physical stigmas of hunger limit a child’s academic performance and future opportunities.

Among the elderly, malnutrition is rampant with as many of 10 million older Americans facing hunger every year. Forced frequently to choose between purchasing healthy food or other necessities such as utilities or medications, our senior population is caught in a financial gauntlet that is greatly harming their health. Food insecure seniors are 50 percent more likely to have diabetes; three times more likely to suffer from depression; 60 percent more likely to have congestive heart failure or heart attack; among other life-altering conditions.

The costs of hunger are equally staggering. America spends approximately $178.9 billion annually on the effects of hunger, $160 billion of which is for health care – more than all annual state and federal spending on higher education.

Such facts are alarming and represent a critical issue that the American healthcare system has largely ignored. As a nation, we have taken a reactive stance to health and well-being for generations. Until recently, healthcare providers were incentivized based on providing costly medical interventions rather than less expensive, but highly effective, preventions. In fact, it costs less to feed an individual healthy food for a year, than to cover the costs of hospitalization and related medical expenses for one day.

It’s obvious that we can no longer afford to ignore the root causes of health. The American healthcare system is being crushed under the weight of a society whose citizens are sicker and more vulnerable than ever before simply because many of their basic needs are going unmet.

America is literally starving for a solution.

Addressing hunger as a health issue is an initiative that must infiltrate healthcare systems nationwide for the sake of the country’s most vulnerable residents and because it is good business.

In northwest Ohio, ProMedica has made a commitment to address the social determinants of health, including food insecurity and its effects on health. Together with community partners, area philanthropists and local physicians/providers, we are targeting both the clinical indicators of food insecurity as well as the social and environmental conditions that perpetuate hunger.

The approach is comprehensive, diverse and multi-dimensional. Efforts include providing a three-day supply of nutrition upon hospital discharge to many who screen positive for food insecurity, writing “prescriptions” to our food clinics for ongoing assistance and support, and owning and operating a not-for-profit grocery store in a food desert in one of our region’s most depressed neighborhoods. Coupled with outreach and interventions, including job training, affordable housing initiatives and financial opportunity counseling, we are working to create a healthier, more prosperous community.

Since ProMedica’s focus on hunger as a health issue began in 2014, we’ve screened nearly 2 million patients for food insecurity and served more than 50,000 people in our food clinics. And, we’re bending the healthcare cost curve amongst this population. Data from Paramount Health Care – our owned insurance provider – shows a 15 percent reduction in per member, per month costs for patients receiving a prescription to our food clinics.

These results are real and tangible – one healthcare system in one region implementing simple measures that drive responsibility and reform to improve health and well-being. Imagine what could be accomplished and sustained if healthcare providers around the country would adopt similar approaches.

We can make the fight against hunger a ‘winnable battle’ through aligned efforts that address food insecurity, improve lives and transform health care.

Randy Oostra, DM, FACHE, is the president and chief executive officer of Toledo, Ohio-based ProMedica, overseeing the 15th largest integrated health and well-being system in the United States. Dr. Oostra is regarded as one of the nation’s most influential leaders in health care. For more than 10 years, he has been a leading visionary and advocate of redefining health care by understanding and addressing the social determinants of health (SDOH). His catalytic leadership and passionate commitment have been the guiding force behind the development of the ProMedica National Social Determinants of Health Institute, which aims to drive healthcare innovation and transformation through SDOH-centered clinical/ social care, community outreach, and research/analytics. For more information, please visit promedica.org/socialdeterminants.

name: Becoming True Care Integrators To Improve Population Health
Title: Becoming True Care Integrators To Improve Population Health
Description:
Becoming True Care Integrators To Improve Population Health

Becoming True Care Integrators To Improve Population Health

By Randy Oostra, DM, FACHE, President and Chief Executive Officer, ProMedica, Toledo, Ohio

As healthcare leaders, we often think primarily in terms of three- to five-year plans. But let’s consider the next 50 years and question ‘what’ and ‘how’ the investments we’re making in our communities — new facilities, programs, initiatives, and more — will impact the public by 2065.

To achieve meaningful results, we believe our industry should take the lead on being the true integrators of care so that both physical and mental health are treated in tandem while other needs are addressed through widespread community collaborations.

That includes marshalling our industry’s resources — including 5,000 hospitals and 650,000 physicians — coupled with a much needed influx of public health funding to improve outcomes nationwide. Primary care providers should not just treat physical health symptoms without consideration for contributing economic and social conditions; they should be repositioned and armed to care for their patients’ overall well-being, including mental health. 

And we should change the way our industry has operated for the last 50 years. The model remains lacking even after moving from a fee-for-service to a value-based care model, and it is time we transition to this integrated approach.

There is no question our industry’s current path is unsustainable. The United States has both a high level of health spending per capita and a relatively high rate of real growth in healthcare spending. The share of U.S. gross domestic product devoted to healthcare spending has grown steadily from 5% in 1965, the year Medicaid and Medicare were established, to 9% in 1980. After crossing into double digits to nearly 13% in 1993, that share is now close to 18%; some projections have it pushing 20% by 2023.

Still, despite leading on healthcare expenditures, life expectancy in the United States lags that of many other developed countries. As healthcare providers, this path is not only unsustainable but unacceptable. It fails to benefit the health and well-being of residents in our communities, the very core of our industry's mission, and our financial health increasingly will depend on making strides in both quality and length of life.

To truly make a difference long term, the healthcare industry must return to its holistic roots and focus on health-related conditions where people live, learn, work and play, as well as foster economic development, educational advancement and social equality.

America will benefit from our efforts to end a fragmented care system that often doesn't address the social determinants of health that have such a major influence on wellness: education, employment, housing, neighborhoods and more.

While clinical care is important, getting to the root cause of why people have diabetes, asthma, poor nutrition, heart conditions and other ailments as a result of their surroundings and behaviors is necessary, too. Research is clear these other factors play an even larger part in determining a community’s overall health than the medical care people receive. We need to work with various partners to provide valuable resources that meet community health needs, both inside and outside of our traditional facilities.

The healthcare industry must not only deliver clinical excellence and efficiency, we must hone in on how we can act as catalysts, innovators and leaders to improve the health of our entire communities. We have to straddle parallel tracks to continue advancing clinical care while ensuring basic needs plus educational opportunities, adequate housing, employment, and other social determinants of health are met. All are inevitably and inextricably linked, and the industry must act to understand and address this relationship.

The social determinants of health are about going beyond our four walls, beyond the episodic moments of care people receive at our hospitals and our physician offices, to those moments where health is actually impacted – in our homes, our schools, and our communities.

Hospitals and health systems will need to focus increasingly on being the integrators of care for communities. We need to concentrate on a model that yields a healthy individual and a healthy community including clinical excellence, social determinants of health, public and private partnerships, economic development, innovative models of care, and education – which ultimately will achieve better outcomes, enhanced quality, greater efficiencies, reduced costs, and improved margins. 

People living in the United States certainly know that environmental and social factors affect their health. From a list of 14 factors that might cause ill health, the top five causes cited as extremely important are lack of access to high-quality medical care; personal behavior; viruses or bacteria; high stress; and exposure to air, water or chemical pollution, according to results of an NPR/Robert Wood Johnson Foundation/Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health poll released in early 2015.

Clearly, a new approach to health care is needed. We believe the key to that approach is as straightforward as addressing our citizens’ basic needs, such as food and clothing, and the social determinants of health.

At ProMedica, we have made strides by collaborating with various individuals and organizations to address the social determinants of health. We are acting as a convener and catalyst to bring individuals, organizations and businesses together. We also are working on integrating clinical care and removing barriers related to other social determinants, including housing, economic development and education. Many of our investments are strategically based on findings from our Community Health Needs Assessment.

These investments should make a difference in and add value to our health outcomes and related environmental and social conditions for the next half century.

name: Art at Toledo Hospital Filled With Love and Healing
Title: Art at Toledo Hospital Filled With Love and Healing
Description:
Art at Toledo Hospital Filled With Love and Healing

Artist Leilani Schweitzer traveled to Toledo from Nevada to install her work at ProMedica Toledo Hospital's new Generations Tower. The piece is called Vera Chroma: Vitality. It will greet patients and visitors as they enter the outpatient surgery lobby. It was those patients and visitors Schweitzer thought about helping as she was creating the piece.

"People's emotional well-being--if they're relaxed, if they're comfortable, if they're optimistic--that improves their healing and improves their outcomes. And that's ultimately what hospitals are here to do, is to make people better and it's not just treatments or procedures or medications, it is treating the spirit as well," explained Schweitzer. "So hopefully, this is part of the way to treat the spirit of patients and their families, and the people who work here as well.

This hospital space is especially meaningful and familiar to Schweitzer. She knows what it's like to be in the hospital under the worst of circumstances. In 2005, when her son Gabriel was 20 months old, he got very sick and Schweitzer entered her community hospital in Nevada expecting doctors to make him well. Instead, her life was shattered.

In a 2013 TEDx talk called Transparency, Compassion and Truth in Medical Errors, Schweitzer recalled the death of her son, which resulted from mistakes made at two different hospitals where he was treated. While both hospitals had the opportunity to learn from her son's death and be transparent, Schweitzer explained that only one of them did.

"He died at Stanford," Schweitzer said. "Stanford investigated, they explained, they apologized and eventually, they gave me a job. So now I work for Stanford. I work with other patients and families who have had unexpected outcomes in their care."

Working with those families and raising awareness about transparency in the healthcare industry has been critical to Schweitzer's own healing process, along with her artwork. She feels her son's presence in every moment. Schweitzer knows each person will see something unique when they view the piece. She hopes every person will feel the love and the hope inspired by a little angel named Gabriel.

"I've had so many people who have worked on this project with me. So many of my family and my friends, my daughter. And to think of all those loving hands touching something that we crate up and ship across the country and hang in a place I've never been before, I think that good intention and that love and healing comes with it. And I hope some of that is reflected in this now," said Schweitzer.

name: Innovative Technology Helps Neurosurgeons with 3D Map of Brain
Title: Innovative Technology Helps Neurosurgeons with 3D Map of Brain
Description:
Innovative Technology Helps Neurosurgeons with 3D Map of Brain

The brain is one of the most complex and vital organs in our body, making brain surgery a complicated procedure that requires an incredible amount of skill and precision. And having the right tools can make a big difference in how a surgeon does this work. That's why, in 2017, ProMedica Toledo Hospital became the first in Ohio to offer BrightMatterTM technology. This 3D mapping technology offers the benefits of a built-in GPS system, giving neurosurgeons the ability to find the best paths for surgey that will minimize damage, reduce recovery time and lead to better patient outcomes. It also allows them to safely remove previously inoperable tumors.

Kevin Reinard, MD, a neurosurgeon with ProMedica Physicians, uses the BrightMatter technology to navigate around sensitive areas to reach a tumor. The technology allows him to remove more of a tumor because he has a clearer picture of how far he can push the boundary without causing harm to the patient.

It starts before the surgery even begins. The patient undergoes what's called a synaptive protocol MRI study, which maps out the brain in very bright colors.

"It allows us to see the white matter tracks--these are the information highways that are in the brain," explains Dr. Reinard. "Things like the capacity to see things, memory function, language function, and so forth. If you can avoid these, patients do well because they'll have no deficits after surgery."

But BrightMatter is only part of the equation. A surgical tool called Modus V works with BrightMatter to give Dr. Reinard a crystal clear magnification of the tumor. Another plus: instead of being hunched over the patient looking through magnifying glasses, the doctor can look straight ahead at a video screen, and see the magnified image from Modus V as he does his work.

"It’s a freestanding robotic arm that you can position in any dimension," says Dr. Reinard. "So I can stand in a comfortable position in front of a patient or beside a patient and the robot can then assume a position that is favorable for me and doesn’t get in the way. If you have to do a case that’s 4, 5, 6 hours long and you’re standing there looking through a microscope or bent over, the element of fatigue is something that factors into the entire process."

Learning the new technique took a little time, but Dr. Reinard is thrilled with the results he's seeing for his patients. Plus, the system is ideal for collaboration and teaching.

"This technology takes it to another level," said Dr. Reinard. "The image is projected onto a big screen where not only can I see it, but also everyone involved including medical students can see. That’s a huge advantage because it’s a great learning tool and educational tool."

While Modus V and BrightMatter are primarily being used for neurosurgery at ProMedica, other physicians are investigating how the innovative system might help a wide variety of patients.

Dr. Reinard says, "This is one very important piece of technology that allows us to do things we couldn’t do before. All in all, it makes us better surgeons."

Erectile Dysfunction Could Be a Telltale Sign of a Vascular Issue

Many underlying reasons could contribute to the cause of erectile dysfunction or ED. These issues vary from a long list of medical problems that include both physical and psychological. Though vascular doctors do not directly treat erectile dysfunction, vascular intervention is often an indirect treatment.

“When we have a patient referred to us for claudication (pain in legs while walking) and peripheral artery disease, often its discovered that the patient has erectile dysfunction,” said Jihad Abbas MD, FACS, ProMedica Physicians Jobst Vascular.

Peripheral artery disease is a common circulatory issue that causes reduced blood flow to limbs and lower extremities. When atherosclerosis (plaque containing fats, cholesterol, and other substances) builds up on the artery walls, it stenoses or narrows the path for blood flow.

Imagine the vascular system as the body’s internal plumbing. The main pipe is the aorta, which branches off blood flow to the internal iliac artery to the pudendal artery. The pudendal artery supplies the blood to the penis, which causes an erection.

“If the aorta or the common iliac artery is significantly stenosed or completely occluded (blocked), you would have decreased blood flow to the penis, which causes ED,” says Abbas.

Other vascular issues that could be a contributor to impotence or ED include nerve damage from aortic surgery and neuropathy caused by diabetes.

“There is a nerve that runs next to the aorta that supplies signals to the area of the penis. If this nerve gets injured (during aortic surgery or from neuropathy) then the patient will have impotence or Erectile Dysfunction (ED) or what we call retrograde ejaculation,” says Abbas.

If you have a family history of vascular disease and are experiencing impotence or ED, consult with your physician for more information.

Know the Signs, Know the Symptoms. May Is National Stroke Awareness Month.

Do you know the signs and symptoms of a stroke? You should. According to the National Stroke Awareness Association (NSA), every 40 seconds someone has a stroke in the United States.

In observance of National Stroke Awareness Month, the Jobst Vascular Institute encourages you to learn the acronym BE FAST as an easy way to remember the signs and symptoms of a stroke.

B – Balance: Is there a sudden loss of balance or coordination?

E – Eyes: Is there sudden blurred or double vision or sudden, persistent vision trouble?

F – Face: Ask the person to smile. Does one side of the face droop?

A – Arms: Ask the person to raise both arms. Does one arm drift downward?

S – Speech: Ask the person to repeat a simple sentence. Is their speech slurred?

T – Time: If you observe any of these signs, call 9-1-1 immediately.

Todd E. Russell MD, FACS of the Jobst Vascular Institute, explains that there are two main types of stroke; hemorrhagic and ischemic. Hemorrhagic is bleeding into the brain and mainly caused by hypertension. 

“Patients who are on anticoagulation medication are also at greater risk (of hemorrhagic stroke),” says Russell.

Ischemic stroke is when there is no blood flow to a portion of the brain due to a blockage in an artery.

“The plaque or clot that causes the blockage usually starts in the heart or the arteries leading to the brain, then dislodges, and travels to the artery feeding the brain. Depending on how long the blockage lasts, a stroke can result,” says Russell.

About 795,000 people have a stroke in the U.S. every year and of that number 140,000 end in death. Stroke is also the leading cause of long-term disability in the U.S. Risk factors include hypertension, atrial fibrillation, smoking, high cholesterol, excessive alcohol consumption, inactivity, age, family history, and ethnicity.

To find out if you’re at risk, talk to your primary care physician.

name: Raising Awareness of Pelvic Pain
Title: Raising Awareness of Pelvic Pain
Description:
Raising Awareness of Pelvic Pain

Raising Awareness of Pelvic Pain

Pelvic pain can be difficult to talk about and sometimes even hard to identify. That’s why the International Pelvic Pain Society has designated May as Pelvic Pain Awareness month, to raise public awareness of chronic pelvic pain and increase access to care for those living with the condition.

One in three women of child-bearing age experiences chronic pelvic pain, but people of all ages and men, too, can experience pelvic pain. Chronic pelvic pain is defined as discomfort that occurs in the lower abdomen for at least six months. It can be caused by a variety of reasons, including pelvic floor disorder, endometriosis, uterine fibroids and musculoskeletal problems.

“Many men and women suffer from pelvic pain, so it’s important to know that if you have pelvic pain, you are not alone,” assured Sara Anderson, PT, DPT, PRPC, ProMedica Pelvic Health.

Trying Physical Therapy

As a pelvic health physical therapist, Anderson has received extra training to help treat conditions of the pelvic floor. She uses a combination of external and internal techniques to stretch and strengthen pelvic floor muscles that support all of the organs in the lower abdomen.

It may be a different type of physical therapy than most of us are used to, but it can be very effective in treating pelvic floor conditions such as chronic pain and incontinence, especially when used in conjunction with medical management.

“It’s important to know you don’t have to live with this pain,” said Anderson. “Pelvic pain is never normal. Intercourse, in particular, should never be painful. You should not have to take off work or school when you’re menstruating due to cramping. Pelvic pain can and should be addressed to allow you to live your life as fully as possible.”

“You don't have to live with this pain. Pelvic pain can and should be addressed to allow you to live your life as fully as possible.”

Tiffany S., a patient from Toledo, didn’t even know pelvic floor physical therapy existed until she was referred by her gynecologist. For years, she faced a string of health issues—a difficult delivery with an episiotomy, an ovarian cyst rupture, heavy menstrual bleeding and a uterine ablation. She struggled with horrible menstrual cramps, rectal pain, and painful sex. Even taking the stairs or sitting could trigger pain.

“When I would sit down, I would lower myself gently at the end because if I didn’t, I would feel this pain shoot up inside of me. When I sneezed it would hurt across the front of me. There were times when I couldn’t take my kids to things and they had to miss stuff because I could not get off the couch,” explained Tiffany. “I felt like I was aging too fast. It made me feel really bad about myself, like I was broken, spent and used up.”

After her first visit with a pelvic pain physical therapist, Tiffany felt different. After a few visits, the pain began to ease up.

“I noticed when I was walking it wasn’t hurting as bad. The pain I had in my bottom went from a terrible pain to a mild discomfort,” said Tiffany.

Sex started to feel better, too.

“I didn’t know that sex didn’t hurt everybody all the time,” she said. “I have an amazing marriage. To have sex be something that was somewhat negative for me to become a positive is emotionally awesome, too.”

What to Expect

Tiffany admits that while pelvic floor physical therapy may seem awkward, it’s not as bad as some may think.

“If you’ve had a pelvic exam, it’s no more embarrassing. The physical therapist does everything she can to make it as discreet and comfortable as possible,” Tiffany explained.

“Many people are hesitant to come in simply because they don’t know what a pelvic floor physical therapist is or what we do,” said Anderson. “Our evaluation and treatments are done in a private room behind a closed door. We like to play music generally to set a nice and relaxing environment. We do not use speculums or stirrups so it’s not quite like a visit to your OB/Gyn.”

For Tiffany, treatment included some of the same activities she was familiar with from her yoga classes, including belly breathing, child’s pose and happy baby pose. However, each treatment plan is tailored to the individual’s situation and goals.

“Some people are concerned physical therapy will increase their pelvic pain. Others feel they’ve already tried so many things they doubt pelvic therapy is what will finally affect their pain,” said Anderson. “We have a variety of interventions we can use to address your pain and will work with you to find out what treatments are most effective for you.”

After seeing how pelvic therapy has improved her life, Tiffany wants to encourage other women to seek help when needed. And, she wants to show her daughters how to serve others while still prioritizing their own needs.

“I’m trying to set a good example for my daughters of how you need to take care of yourself,” Tiffany said.” Just like on the airplane, if you’re not getting your own oxygen first you can’t put a mask on someone else. You’ve got to take care of yourself and get your body working correctly.”

name: Could a Live Concert Improve Your Health
Title: Could a Live Concert Improve Your Health?
Description:
Could a Live Concert Improve Your Health?

Could a Live Concert Improve Your Health?

Health is much more than living free from illness. The World Health Organization (WHO) defines health as “a state of complete physical, mental and social well-being not merely the absence of disease or infirmity.” Experiencing physical health, as well as an overall sense of happiness, is the key to well-being.

Music is a powerful contributor to happiness, and can directly impact physiological health. When we listen to a favorite song, the chemical dopamine is released in the brain. Dopamine is the neurotransmitter responsible for fending off depression and helping us feel good. When we feel good, our body releases more antibodies, therefore enhancing our immune system.

Music is connected to various health benefits, including:

  • Decreased stress: Music decreases stress, which is highly linked to disease and illness.
  • Reduced pain: Music therapy often reduces pain in cancer and fibromyalgia patients.
  • Improved sleep: Music has the ability to improve sleep quality for people of all ages.
  • Healthy aging: Listening to music exercises the brain, keeping us younger for longer.
  • Stroke recovery: Music can improve memory functioning. Patients recovering from stroke often experience better cognitive recovery by listening to music daily.
  • Therapy for Alzheimer’s patients: Music affects so many different areas of the brain. For Alzheimer’s patients, it can stimulate healthy brain pathways to improve cognition and memory.

Live music, live longer? New research suggests a connection between listening to live music and longevity. The study revealed that by attending a concert regularly, people experienced a 25 percent increase in feelings of well-being, 25 percent increase in feelings of self-worth, and 75 percent improvement in mental stimulation. “It is a visual for our patients to see and know how we feel about the service and experience that we want them to have,” said Sheehy. “Having the mural front and center is also a visual for our staff to remember why we are here, that patients come first, that everyone has a different idea of what an excellent experience is and that it is up to us to ask what that is and deliver.”

Description:
Veggie Mobile Delivers Nutrition Throughout Lenawee County

Each week, people in rural communities like Morenci, Mich., look forward to a visit from the Veggie Mobile.

"It runs Monday through Friday all year long," explained driver Stacy Tilton. "When the weather's great, we set up outside. It's a great service. We're offering fruits and vegetables at very affordable prices."

"I always get avocados for my husband," said customer Joyce Woerner. "And whatever I feel like eating the next week. I noticed some cherries over there and the last ones I bought were super delicious."

The Veggie Mobile is a community outreach program in Lenawee County, where people in many rural communities don't have access to fresh fruits and vegetables.

"Many have the wrong idea that in rural communities there aren't food deserts, and there are," said Julie Yaroch, DO, President, Bixby and Herrick Hospitals. "And I think we even have a greater challenge when it comes to access and transportation because we're a community of over 750 square miles."  

"Many have the wrong idea that in rural communities there aren't food deserts...and I think we even have a greater challenge when it comes to access and transportation."

Tilton, manager, ProMedica Farms, drives the Veggie Mobile across many of those miles and makes sure everyone has the opportunity to afford fresh produce.

"It's open to anyone. You don't have to be a senior or you don't have to be low income," said Tilton. "We do accept Senior Project Fresh coupons. We accept SNAP/EBT. We have 'double up food bucks,' which is just a great program to really stretch those food dollars and just help families eat better."

The Veggie Mobile supports local farms and businesses by buying their produce and items donated by community farms or grown at the new ProMedica Farm are offered to customers for free.

"From time to time, you'll see a need," said Tilton. "ProMedica is generous; we have the ability; we can donate to someone in need. Maybe they're in between pay periods or maybe they had an expense that they weren't expecting. Nobody goes without with the Veggie Mobile."

Tilton takes time to educate the customers about the produce that's available, providing recipes for people to try at home. She's also a friendly face customers look forward to seeing each week.

"She loves everybody; everybody loves her," said Woerner. "What more can I say? She just is so good for everybody and to everybody"

"It's just been a joy, to see people week after week," said Tilton. "And working for a healthcare system, it's like whole health. Knowing that there's somebody out there that cares about you and wants to make sure that you're basic needs are met. It's just been a real joy for me and I think [customers], too."

"I think what Stacy is doing and what the rest of the staff are doing on the farm and Veggie Mobile is about [touching people] and hopefully modeling a behavior that will be shared with someone else so that we can inspire others," said Dr. Yaroch.

"If you go anywhere where there's the Veggie Mobile you'll get good service and you'll get good food," said Woerner.

Janet was entertaining her family over the Easter holiday when she felt an onset of pain that she could not explain. As she lead the meal preparation for over 20 guests Janet was feeling a squeezing sensation in her chest and felt she needed to sit down for a break. Throughout the morning the pain, nausea and sweating continued she decided to go into the emergency room thinking possible heart attack, driven by her daughter.

When she arrived at ProMedica Monroe Regional Hospital’s emergency department, the 71 year old calmly explained that she thought she was having a heart attack. Immediately she was rushed to a bed for an electrocardiogram (ECG) to check the electrical activity of her heart.

The team discovered that Janet was having a life-threatening heart attack referred to as a widowmaker, the informal term for a heart attack that involves 100 percent blockage in the left anterior descending (LAD) artery. That obstruction chokes oxygen, which can trigger an abnormal heart rhythm known as ventricular fibrillation.

Time is a crucial component of treatment. There is a direct correlation between the amount of time a heart artery is obstructed, the seriousness of the heart attack and the likelihood of survival. That’s why cardiologists across the nation believe in the mantra “time is muscle” when treating heart attack patients.

As heart attacks go, a widowmaker can be particularly lethal because of the location and extent of the blockage. In surgery Dr. Vincent Songco placed two stents, a metal or plastic tube, into Janet’s artery to keep it open. With the stents in position Janet recalls feeling better almost immediately stating “Dr. Songco save my life. God put him there that day.”

Following her procedure Janet touted the efforts of not only Dr. Songco but the entire Cardiac Cath Lab “call team” consisting of cardiac techs, monitor techs and circulating nurses. All of which are on call 24/7, 365 days a year. She is thankful that such amazing services are available right here in our community. “You don't need to be sent out of town to receive lifesaving treatment.”

Today in cardiac rehab she is doing more each day as her strength returns. Janet did wear a LifeVest (personal defibrillator worn by a patient at risk for sudden cardiac arrest) for three months and praises her rehab therapist for helping her in recovery. A recovery that has brought her back to her routine of regular walks and caring for her family in her hometown Monroe, Michigan.

name: Protecting Young Players on the Field
Title: Protecting Young Players on the Field
Description:
Protecting Young Players on the Field

Protecting Young Players on the Field

A growing level of awareness about the long-term effects of concussions has changed the way coaches and doctors react to brain injuries that occur on the field.

Yet Ryan Szepiela, MD, ProMedica Physicians Physical Medicine & Rehabilitation, says there’s more research and work to be done.

“There’s a lot of difference in severity of hits and some we still need to recognize,” explained Dr. Szepiela. “It all depends on the type of trauma, what areas of the brain are hit, the severity of the hit, the overall symptoms and how long they take to resolve afterwards.”

Coaches, particularly in football, have been incorporating safer techniques, such as keeping feet down when tackling to lower a risk for concussion or cervical spine injury. They also have to participate in training to be able to recognize concussions, as well as what to do if a player has one and how they are treated. Plus, a visit with a certified health provider is needed for the player to get back on the field.

The symptoms of a concussion can really vary. In general, a concussion is a type of traumatic brain injury (TBI) that is caused by a bump, blow or jolt to the head that disrupts normal brain function. While some players just feel dazed for a few minutes, others can have lingering effects, like sleep or concentration problems for several weeks.

Concussion symptoms vary. While some players just feel dazed for a few minutes, others can have lingering effects, like sleep or concentration problems for several weeks.

A return to play protocol is set to help a child with a concussion recover safely. “We test and evaluate the child with the head injury and have computer testing where we can help see if they are back to a baseline or if they still have cognitive or functional issues,” said Dr. Szepiela.

While physicians and coaches are working to make sports safer, parents have a responsibility, too, to protect their child. With no general rules about when a child should begin contact sports, parents have to consider their child’s individual skills and capabilities.

“Kids develop at different ages; kids become mature at different ages as well. Should your child be out there? Can they control their own body to even be taught to tackle correctly?” explained Dr. Szepiela. “If your child wants to play, you have to go there and actually evaluate to make sure they are doing the right thing for them. As a parent, you have to be involved in the process, and be present for things to make sure they are going correctly.

Changes to the game and to concussion treatment are making sports safer, especially in the age range where the brain is developing quickly. Dr. Speziela said he hopes the momentum continues, with awareness and research.

“Awareness is key in keeping our kids and athletes safe as they move up the chain and continue to play contact sports,” he said.

name: The Basics about Brain Aneurysms
Title: The Basics about Brain Aneurysms
Description:
The Basics about Brain Aneurysms

The Basics about Brain Aneurysms

September is Brain Aneurysm Awareness month, and with an estimated 1 in 50 Americans having an unruptured brain aneurysm, according to the Brain Aneurysm Foundation, it’s important to increase awareness about this condition.

In a Facebook Live interview with Chrys Peterson, Kevin Reinard, MD, a neurosurgeon with ProMedica Physicians, explained that aneurysms are essentially a blister that forms on the blood vessel in the brain.

Watch the Facebook Live interview

“If there’s a weakness in the wall of the blood vessel, that section of the blood vessel has a tendency to ‘pouch out’ and creates a blister. That blister has a tendency to rupture,” he said. 

Many times, patients aren’t even aware they have an aneurysm because they may not experience any symptoms or problems. However, advanced imaging technologies have made them easier to spot.

“We’re seeing a lot more aneurysms discovered early because if someone has a headache or sustains an injury to the head, for example, they may obtain a scan of the head, which may show an incident of an aneurysm,” said Dr. Reinard.

In these cases, patients should get in touch with a neurologist or a neurosurgeon to discuss potential treatment options. The treatment will depend on various factors, and some individuals may just be monitored if the aneurysm is considered low risk.

“Not all aneurysms are dangerous. It depends on the location, the size of the aneurysm and the overall condition of the person.”

“Not all aneurysms are dangerous,” explained Dr. Reinard. “It depends on the location, the size of the aneurysm and the overall condition of the person. The vast majority of the aneurysms that I see in my clinic, we simply follow for a long period of time.”

At ProMedica, a collective team of neurosurgeons, stroke neurologists and other professionals meet monthly to discuss patient conditions and come up with a plan that best suits each individual. There are certain risk factors that can increase the likelihood of an aneurysm rupture.

Aneurysms in certain locations of the brain have a higher probability of rupturing, and it’s been known that in females the tendency to rupture is a little bit higher than in men,” said Dr. Reinard. “Smoking is also a very high risk factor. If you smoke and you have a history of an aneurysm, you certainly ought to stop smoking. There are also some genetic disorders; if somebody has a connective tissue disorder, they could potentially be at a higher risk for rupture.”

For the general public, Aneurysm Awareness Month presents an opportunity to understand what aneurysms are and their potential to rupture. And, to keep an eye out for loved ones.

“If you know of somebody who has an aneurysm who has neglected care, they should get in touch with their family physician or see a specialist,” he said. “It’s also important to know that the aneurysm could potentially rupture and cause complications. If you know somebody who has been acting different, hasn’t been themselves, has a headache, their personality has changed, be aware that it could potentially be an aneurysm rupture.”

name: Gluing Veins Shut Can Help Treat Varicose Veins
Title: Gluing Veins Shut Can Help Treat Varicose Veins
Description:
Gluing Veins Shut Can Help Treat Varicose Veins

Gluing Veins Shut Can Help Treat Varicose Veins

When it comes to vein treatments, Rochelle Peterman has been through it all.

She’s had venous insufficiency, also known as venous reflux, for decades after having children. “It can get very painful—throbbing, aching, a lot of swelling, a feeling of heaviness when you’re moving around,” she explained.

The condition occurs when the valves in the veins don’t work properly. Instead of taking all of the blood back to the heart, the faulty veins cause blood to head in the wrong direction, leading to pressure in the veins, widened veins and pain. A trademark symptom is the snake-like shape of varicose veins. But beside their unpleasant appearance, Rochelle knew it was a priority to work with doctors for health reasons. “It’s a true medical condition that you want to have addressed because it can lead to a lot of complication if you don’t.”

Rochelle tried a few treatments, including bi-lateral stripping to remove some of the major veins and sclerotherapy. Unfortunately, none of these treatments worked. Thankfully, she was willing to try another treatment—VenaSeal, a procedure that actually glues veins shut.

“The substance is a version of super glue–the same substance that has been developed for other medical purposes, such as deep cuts in the emergency room, ” explained John Fish, MD, FSVM, FACP, a vascular medicine physician with Jobst Vascular Institute. A higher thickness in the glue helps it work in the vein and pressure from the outside (by pressing on the skin) allows the glue to set. The procedure’s effectiveness is very high, in the 90% range, said Dr. Fish.

Rochelle is part of that 90%.

“I can’t say enough good about it,” she said. “They did a local anesthetic on the back of my left calf. I felt a little pinch of the catheter go in. After that it was smooth sailing.” On the day of Rochelle’s procedure, she couldn’t drive and needed to keep her leg elevated for about an hour or so at a time. She also needed to be walking around. But by the next day, it was life as usual.

“I was able to go about the tasks of daily living by day two,” said Rochelle. “There was no incision, just a tiny scab where they put the catheter.”

Dr. Fish agreed that there is typically isn’t much pain with the procedure. “We are basically starting a line, like an IV, in the calf region. The wire goes up and from there there really isn’t a lot of pain,” he described.

“In the past, we had to make multiple injections of fluid that goes around the vein,” he said. “So we had the wire inside the vein, and we had to inject from the outside to put a halo of fluid around the vein so we could turn on an energy source such as a laser or radio frequency probe that caused the vein to shut. In this case, we don’t have to do this; that step is eliminated.”

According to Dr. Fish, there aren’t a lot of known side effects from the VenaSeal glue itself, either. These procedures where we shut these veins do carry a less than 1% risk of a clot that can form at the end where we start in the groin, for example,” he said. “It’s a low percentage, but we usually have everybody come back for an ultrasound just to check in case that happens.”

Venous insufficiency can present itself, as it did in Rochelle’s case, after pregnancy because the veins widen when you are pregnant and the uterus puts added pressure on the veins. Hereditary factors can also contribute to the condition, but Dr. Fish said that even people without a family history can develop venous insufficiency from the work they do or from being on their feet all the time. Conservative treatments, such as compression socks aren’t always enough to help the swelling and pain if the venous insufficiency is more advanced.

“There’s so much blood flow going in the wrong direction in the vein because of faulty veins,” explained Dr. Fish.

That’s where treatments like VenaSeal come in. Rochelle was a little nervous about the procedure at first, but is now glad she did it. “There is no pain in my leg; no heaviness,” she said.

name: Teacher One of First in Ohio for Vascular Procedure
Title: Teacher One of First in Ohio for Vascular Procedure
Description:
Teacher One of First in Ohio for Vascular Procedure

As a kindergarten teacher, Katie Bernath’s day is pretty much non-stop. “Lots of hands-on, lots of tying shoes, bending over at tables helping students one on one…I don’t really get any breaks…it’s hard to find time to go to the bathroom,” said Katie.

It became a huge challenge a couple of years ago when Katie felt the urge to use the bathroom every few minutes. “I thought I had a UTI [urinary tract infection], and instead of going to the doctor I had them prescribe something over the phone. I got better but I was still going to the bathroom every 5-10 minutes, I felt like I had to go.”

Turns out, it wasn’t a urinary tract infections–and her symptoms got worse.

“I did a lot of sitting. I was very tired. I was in a lot of pain,” said Katie. “I remember my fiancé was with me and I couldn’t move, I couldn’t stand up straight, I was in so much pain. I said, “I have to go to the hospital.”

Katie was just 25 years old so she was surprised when tests showed she might have a vascular problem. Andrew Seiwert, MD, from Jobst Vascular Institute, looked at Katie’s scans and knew right away what was wrong.

“He came back and said, ‘Yep, it’s nutcracker syndrome,’ and I said, ‘OK, what’s that?'” explained Katie.

Nutcracker syndrome is a type of pelvic congestion syndrome–a condition caused by varicose veins in the lower abdomen that can cause severe pain, make it difficult to sit or ride in a car, and, in Katie’s case, it was affecting her kidney function.

“With nutcracker syndrome, you have to think of an old-fashioned nutcracker. If the angle is bad, the artery clamps down on the vein,” said Dr. Seiwert. “All of the blood going into the left kidney can’t get out of the left kidney, and so it’s looking for someplace else to go.”

“Probably the easiest way of thinking about that is to back as a kid putting a rubber band on your finger,” explained Dr. Seiwert. “It’s fun to watch your finger turn purple, but after about 30-45 seconds, it becomes painful because the blood gets into your finger but can’t get out.”

Correcting that issue used to mean major surgery with a 12-18 inch incision and up to a year of recovery. But Katie opted to try a new procedure, developed just two years ago by Chicago surgeon John White. With laparoscopic surgery and a much smaller incision, a general surgeon moves the bowel out of the way temporarily so Dr. Seiwert can easily reach and repair the vascular issue, just a 2-3 hour procedure.

“When John White published this in 2016, it was an ‘ah ha’ moment,” said Dr. Seiwert. “We have had great success with this so far and think it’s the way to go.”

Katie is now not only a teacher, but a bit of a pioneer–one of the first patients in Ohio to undergo this new procedure. Just three weeks after surgery, she was back in the classroom and back to her old self again.

“It’s fun! I can bend over, I have no pain. If I have to go to the bathroom, it’s not like it was a year and a half ago,” said Katie. “100% I’d do the surgery all over again. I feel like I’m a better teacher for it.”

Title: #OhioWearsBlue to Raise Awareness of Child Abuse and Neglect
Description:
#OhioWearsBlue to Raise Awareness of Child Abuse and Neglect

#OhioWearsBlue to Raise Awareness of Child Abuse and Neglect

On April 11, residents throughout Ohio donned blue to raise awareness of child abuse and neglect in our communities. The campaign, led by the Public Children Services Association of Ohio, aims to engage business, community service organizations, schools, civic organizations and healthcare organizations to participate in a one-day awareness event. The campaign is also in the midst of National Child Abuse Prevention Month.

In addition to negatively impacting a child’s well-being, studies suggest that abuse and neglect may have damaging effects on emotional and physical health, perhaps even contributing to premature death.

“When a child is abused there is usually more than one type of abuse happening,” explained ProMedica clinical psychologist Adrienne Fricker Elhai, PhD, The Cullen Center. “Their environment lacks support and they don’t develop the proper skills to be an adult.”

Awareness of the effects of neglect is particularly important due to its effects. Neglect is the absence of care and can be physical, emotional or medical.

“Research shows the long-term effects of neglect are often more profound than abuse,” said Dr. Elhai. “Babies and children learn about the world, themselves, and others within the context of relationships and when they are neglected, this learning is disrupted.”

According to Dr. Elhai, children who are consistently neglected have no one to let them know that they matter and will likely have difficulty with trust and understanding their own and other’s moods, which will make relationships difficult.

Child abuse and neglect can be prevented, but it takes awareness and the right connect to resources. If you suspect a child has been a victim of abuse or neglect, call Child Protective Services. In Lucas County, the number is 419-213-CARE (2273).

“One positive adult in a child’s life can make all the difference for a child who is being abused,” said Dr. Elhai. “Having a supportive individual around may change that child’s path.”

name: New FDAApproved Drug May Help Those With Migraines
Title: New FDA-Approved Drug May Help Those With Migraines
Description:
New FDA-Approved Drug May Help Those With Migraines

New FDA-Approved Drug May Help Those With Migraines

Kris Gilmore Tolek has had migraines since her early teens and now gets them nearly every day. “I get bad migraines a couple times a week and more mild ones on the other days,” she explained. The debilitating condition also runs in her family.

Desperate for relief, she has tried a variety of treatments. “I’ve tried many supposed migraine and off-label medications, such as nerve blocks, chiropractor and bio feedback—and have gotten either no relief or some relief but with many side effects.”

Ms. Gilmore Tolek is one of many to live with migraines. Selena Nicholas-Bublick, MD, ProMedica neurologist, said there are up to 39 million migraine sufferers in the country.

Fortunately, the recent approval from the U.S. Food and Drug Administration of a drug that prevents migraines gives patients like Ms. Gilmore Tolek hope. The drug, called Aimovig™, blocks a molecule in the brain that helps trigger migraines. It is a monthly injection that the patient usually injects into their thigh.

According to Dr. Nicholas-Bublick, there are other migraine therapies out there already but studies have shown that patients are dissatisfied, either because they aren’t effective enough or because there are side effects. “It’s frustrating to patients and care providers, and it can unfortunately lead to overuse of acute pain medications,” she said.

So how does Aimovig work? Dr. Nicholas-Bublick explained that during a migraine, certain molecules in the brain are released. One molecule in particular, called CGRP (calcitonin gene-related peptide) plays an important role in causing pain. Aimovig blocks this molecule from getting to a receptor, which would cause pain.

Aimovig is a little different from other medications because it’s taken through the skin as an injection. So far, it’s showing promising results with limited side effects, said Dr. Nicholas-Bublick.

Ms. Gilmore Tolek is hopeful it will work for her, too.

name: How Contagious Is Hepatitis A From a Restaurant
Title: How Contagious Is Hepatitis A From a Restaurant?
Description:
How Contagious Is Hepatitis A From a Restaurant?

How Contagious Is Hepatitis A From a Restaurant?

A recent case of Hepatitis A at a Toledo Dave and Buster’s is concerning local patrons who recently dined there. But how contagious is this condition?

According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), “hepatitis A is a highly contagious liver infection caused by the hepatitis A virus” which causes the liver to become inflamed. The prevalence of hepatitis A has decreased since the vaccine was introduced in 1995, but it’s still common and contagious.

However, the likelihood of getting it from a food worker may not be as high as you think. Michael Basista, MD, a gastroenterologist with ProMedica Physicians, said that patrons have a fairly low risk of acquiring hepatitis A from a restaurant employee. Like other viruses, it’s spread when food, typically uncooked food (such as a salad) or already cooked food, is touched by the person infected. “If they didn’t wash their hands they could pass it on,” he explained.

“Other employees are at a somewhat higher risk because they work alongside the person,” said Dr. Basista. Immediate family, too, is also at risk. For these people, a hepatitis A vaccination is recommended.

Fatigue, fever, yellowish skin (jaundice), and vomiting are some of the symptoms of hepatitis A, although young children often show no or very few symptoms. Those with certain preexisting conditions, or who previously had untreated hepatitis B or C may get sicker than the average person. Symptoms typically last for about 1-2 months, but could last up to six months in rare cases. The virus is contagious for up to two weeks, even before some symptoms appear, making it difficult to prevent it from spreading.

The good news: “Hepatitis A doesn’t cause a chronic condition and once you have it you’re immune,” said Dr. Basista. Having hepatitis A also doesn’t increase your risk for cirrhosis or cancer.

Dr. Basista recommends that those with liver problems or other significant health problems ask their doctors about the hepatitis A vaccination if they may have been exposed.

name: Carol Buchanans Brain Aneurysm Story
Title: Carol Buchanan's Brain Aneurysm Story
Description:
All in the Family

All in the Family

All in the Family: A Brain Aneurysm Survivor Shares Her Story

 

Imagine waking up one day in a hospital room without any recollection of how you got there. Your laptop, favorite blanket and cell phone are near your bedside. You scroll through your phone and find three days’ worth of text messages from worried loved ones. You realize that you have been in the hospital for three days. You are frightened, worried and have so many questions.

That’s what happened to Carol Buchanan two years ago. She woke up to find herself in ProMedica Toledo Hospital. Her husband, Frank Buchanan, had to explain to her everything that had happened over the few days.

It started on Nov. 28, 2015. That night, Frank heard Carol making strange noises in her sleep. He turned on the light to check on her. That’s when he realized she was not breathing. He called 911 immediately. Within minutes, the ambulance arrived. Paramedics administered CPR and rushed Carol to the emergency room at Toledo Hospital. There, she was diagnosed with a ruptured brain aneurysm.

Each year, a brain aneurysm ruptures in 10 out of every 100,000 people, according to the National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke. A brain aneurysm is a bulge in a blood vessel in the brain. As the aneurysm grows, it places pressure on the surrounding tissues in the brain. Eventually, it can rupture.

Like most people with a brain aneurysm, Carol didn’t know that she was living with one until it burst. It released blood into the spaces around her brain. This is a subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH), a very serious type of stroke. According to the Brain Aneurysm Foundation, approximately 15% of patients with SAH die before ever reaching the hospital.

To save Carol, Mouhammad Jumaa, MD, interventional vascular neurologist, performed an emergency endovascular coiling surgery. Dr. Jumaa guided a catheter through Carol’s groin to reach the affected blood vessel in her brain where the aneurysm was located. Then, small metal coils were inserted into the aneurysm. They conformed to the shape of the aneurysm and stopped the bleeding.

Carol survived the procedure. However, Dr. Jumaa warned her loved ones that she would be fortunate to make it through the night and, if she did, she likely would not have the same brain function as she did before. Loved ones came to the hospital to say their final goodbyes. Incredibly, three days later, Carol woke up.

Read more: Brain Aneurysm Care

Her recovery progressed over several months. While in the hospital, she began speech, physical, and occupational therapy. Then, she moved to ProMedica Flower Hospital, where she continued intense inpatient rehab. Once out of the hospital, Carol completed three more months of outpatient rehab.

“Everything is back to normal now, including the fact that I still don’t like to cook,” Carol shared. She knows that she was extremely lucky. Of those who survive a ruptured brain aneurysm, like Carol did, 66% suffer permanent neurological deficits.

 
After Carol's brain aneurysm burst, loved ones started to say their final goodbyes. Not only did she survive, she's now an advocate for prevention.

Six months after her aneurysm ruptured, Carol began to have regular follow-up visits at Toledo Hospital’s brain aneurysm clinic. She laughs now when recalling her first appointment with Julie Shawver, PA-C, ProMedica Physicians Neurology.

“Julie told me we’d get to be best friends. I thought to myself, ‘No, I’d just like to go on with my life now,’” Carol said. “But sure enough, she was right.”

In addition to seeing Dr. Jumaa, Julie, and other caregivers at her regular visits to the aneurysm clinic, Carol also looks forward to seeing them each September at ProMedica’s annual celebration for brain aneurysm survivors.

“It’s overwhelming. It’s wonderful to laugh with them and to see them outside of the doctor’s office, especially with lemonade and cake,” she adds.

Her advice to others: Pay attention to your family history. Brain aneurysms can be hereditary. In fact, her father and a niece passed away from ruptured brain aneurysms. Today, she encourages her family members to talk with their doctors about their personal risk and, if needed, to have testing done at the brain aneurysm clinic at Toledo Hospital.

Dr. Jumaa lists other risk factors for developing brain aneurysms including cigarette smoking, high blood pressure, injury or trauma to blood vessels, and complications from certain blood infections.

“To diagnose a brain aneurysm, patients need special imaging tests,” he explains. “If an unruptured brain aneurysm is discovered, it can be monitored and a potential rupture can be prevented using medical or surgical treatments.”
